speaker: Teacher
text: Now, because French has so many different vowel sounds, we want to pay special attention to how the vowel might change because of a written accent, as we've seen with the E, for example, no? We have, "le," [schwa sound] "je," [schwa sound] "recommander," [schwa R sound with nasal 'a' sound] no? Where the E has no accent. And then we have like, "è," [French 'eh' sound] like in "réserver." [French 'eh' sound] We also saw the E with the little hat on the top, like in "fête," [French 'eh' sound] "party," like school fete in English. And we also want to notice how a vowel might change forming part of a combination of letters, no? We've seen, for example, "EU," no? As in, "peu," "un peu," [nasal 'un' sound] "je peux," as in, "veux." And we've seen "OI," like in "je dois," [French 'wa' sound] giving us a "wa" [French 'wa' sound] sound. But it's not just combinations of vowels. For example, we've also seen how N's and M's on the end of syllables combine with the previous vowels to change their sound, like in "confirmer." [nasal 'a' sound] We can revise this actually counting to three in French. So, the number "one" is the same as "A." So what is "A" for masculine like in "a little"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Un, [nasal 'un' sound] now so for "one" we have "un," [nasal 'un' sound] like in "un peu," [nasal 'un' sound] no? That reminds us of how the N gets swallowed into that U and how it changes the pronunciation. And then "une" [pronounced N] for the feminine, with the E on the end, giving us two syllables really, 'cause it should be "u-ne," although that E generally isn't pronounced in most dialects of French, so we get "une." [pronounced N] So this reminds us of how the N combines with the U, or talking more generally, how the N or the M on the end of a syllable can combine with the previous vowel and change its sound. The word for "two" in French is spelled "D-E-U-X." "D-E-U-X." So how do you say "two," like the number "two" in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Deux. [French 'eu' sound] So we have "un," [nasal 'un' sound] "deux," [French 'eu' sound] spelled "D-E-U-X." This reminds us of the "EU" combination, no? We have the silent X on the end again. And "EU" like in "je veux," [French 'eu' sound] "de." [French 'eu' sound] And "de" actually is related to like "duo." The word for "three" in French is "trois." [French 'wa' sound] Spelled "T-R-O-I-S." So again, we have the "O-I" there giving us "wa," [French 'wa' sound] just like in "je dois," [French 'wa' sound] "I must." "Un," [nasal 'un' sound] "deux," [French 'eu' sound] "trois." [French 'wa' sound] So if we put our energy into trying to inspire ourselves to analyze the French we expose ourselves to, look what we got out of just "one," "two," "three," when we look at it through that analytical eye. Just trying to think and find examples of what we know through the French that we expose ourselves to, things that we recognize that make us think. And in this way, we don't have to worry about forgetting anything. Everything is always just out there in the French that you expose yourself to, waiting for you to clarify your doubts looking at it. Give me again "I must."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu dois." "She must," she has to is "elle doit." "Elle doit."

speaker: Teacher
text: And for sure you've seen and heard this around in marketing again, like in fragrances and fashion, perfumes and the like. "Elle," spelled "E-L-L-E," has the same final E that we have in "une" [pronounced N] and many other feminine nouns like "porte," "baguette," et cetera. Now, the first E of "elle" sounds like 'eh' [open 'e' sound] rather than the E, how the E usually sounds without an accent like in "je," [schwa sound] "de." [schwa sound] And that's because what we read is the combination of "E-L" rather than just the E. We read the syllable, "E-L," giving us "elle." [open 'e' sound] So we have "elle doit" [open 'e' sound] for "she must." How would you say "she must visit," "she has to visit"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Elle doit visiter." [open 'e' sound] So we saw how with "elle" [open 'e' sound] we have this E without an accent which we're used to sounding like "eu," as in "je," [schwa sound] "de," [schwa sound] but taking on a different sound when it combines as a syllable with the letter L and we get "elle," [open 'e' sound] spelled "E-L-L-E." So be them combinations of vowels or vowels with consonants, we want to get in the habit of noticing syllables and the sounds that they give us. Actually, phonetic writing, like writing one sound per letter, as far as we know, was invented just once in all of history. All phonetic alphabets, like the English or Latin alphabet, no? Like Greek, like Arabic, all share the same roots. They all sprung from the same crazy thought of dividing up language into unique sounds rather than into syllables. This is because it's so much more intuitive and sensible actually to think about syllables in language rather than individual sounds. So that means to think about "po," "pa," "pi," rather than thinking of P and "ah" separately, which is what most writing systems did. Most writing systems developed syllabaries. So in French, although we use the Latin alphabet, which is phonetic, we might want to get in the habit of thinking in syllables, which is much more intuitive, recognizing combinations of letters and thinking in those combinations of letters. So give me again "she must."

speaker: Teacher
text: Elle doit." [open 'e' sound] "She wants" is "elle veut." [open 'e' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Elle veut." [open 'e' sound] How would you say "she wants it"? "She wants it"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Elle le veut." [open 'e' sound] Good. "Elle le veut." [open 'e' sound] So we have "elle," [open 'e' sound] the word for "she," coming first in the same way that we had "je," "I," for example, coming first. No, "je le veux," "elle le veut." [open 'e' sound] "Elle le veut," [open 'e' sound] "she wants it." And it could also mean "she wants him," no? There we have a masculine and general it, and also him. How would you say "she wants it"? And we mean a feminine it.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Elle la veut." [open 'e' sound] And of course that could also mean "she wants her." So whilst we have "elle" [open 'e' sound] for "she," "la" now is "her." "Elle la veut." [open 'e' sound] "She wants it," a feminine thing, or "she wants her." What was again, "the party"?

speaker: Teacher
text: La fête." [French 'eh' sound] And this is spelled "F-E," and that E has the little hat on the top, the circumflex. "La fête." [French 'eh' sound] "To the party" is "à la fête." [French 'eh' sound] "À la fête." [French 'eh' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: She wants to invite her to the party. So, let's divide the idea up in our minds, no? The first bit is "she wants."

speaker: Teacher
text: Elle veut." [open 'e' sound] To invite her, that's the second bit we must treat that all together, "to invite her."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Elle veut l'inviter," [open 'e' sound] "to the party."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Elle veut l'inviter [open 'e' sound] à la fête." [French 'eh' sound] How would you say, "She wants to invite me to the party"?

speaker: Student
text: Elle veut m'inviter à la fête.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Elle veut m'inviter [open 'e' sound] à la fête." [French 'eh' sound] And if we want to make that a question, does she want to invite me to the party, we can just do that with our intonation if we like. So, how would that be? Does she want to invite me to the party?

speaker: Student
text: Elle veut m'inviter à la fête?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Elle veut m'inviter [open 'e' sound] à la fête." [French 'eh' sound] The "birthday party" is "la fête d'anniversaire." [French 'eh' sound] "La fête d'anniversaire." [French 'eh' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: So, "d'anniversaire" is, "de," "of," now like in "demander." And "anniversaire," sticking together, "d'anniversaire." D, apostrophe, anniversaire. So, "she wants to invite him to the birthday party." "She wants to invite him."

speaker: Student
text: Elle veut l'inviter à la fête d'anniversaire.

speaker: Teacher
text: Elle veut l'inviter [open 'e' sound] à la fête d'anniversaire." [French 'eh' sound] So, "fête d'anniversaire" [French 'eh' sound] is birthday party, no? And what is "anniversaire"? What is that in English?

speaker: Teacher
text: Anniversary, good. And here we have another pattern, actually. "Anniversaire," "anniversary." So, "ary" can become "aire" in French. So, "necessary" might become what in French if we replace the "ary" with "aire"? "Necessary."

speaker: Teacher
text: Nécessaire." And that ending is spelled "A-I-R-E," pronounced "aire." "Nécessaire."

speaker: Teacher
text: Solitaire." Like, like the card game on the computer, no? "Solitaire." Extraordinary.

speaker: Teacher
text: Extraordinaire." So, we see that French is not a simple language to reproduce by reading it, no? But we've also seen that we want to focus on letter combinations to digest what is happening in French. We saw the "O-I" and how it gives us oi, and the "E-U" and how it gives us eu. We've seen how an O gives us oh, but how an "O-N" gives us a nasal 'oh' sound, and how an I gives us 'ih', as in "bicyclette," but how an "I-N" gives us a nasal 'in' sound, like in "invite." So, we will continue ordering all of this information. Now, the most important thing is to get in the habit of analyzing and also trying to find examples of what we know and what we think we know in the French that we come across. And then, this way not panicking, not trying to memorize because memorizing as well, and the habit of memorizing, lets a lot of information get crossed over and confused. And what we're doing is something else. We're learning to constantly analyze with our curiosity and to use the French that we come across and that we expose ourselves to, to remind ourselves of what we know. And to clarify what we're not so sure of.
